translated: Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 19
Composed by 500 great arhats and others
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial command
It can take the three realms of suffering and accumulation as objects, but not simultaneously.
It means taking the desire realm as object in different moments,
and taking the form and formless realms as objects in different moments.
Why can't it take the three realms of suffering or accumulation as objects all at once in a single moment?
If it takes the desire realm as object, it also increases.
It takes the form and formless realms as objects but does not increase.
Why does it take the desire realm as object and also increase,
but take the form and formless realms as objects and not increase?
It is because the desire realm is the place where it increases,
but the form and formless realms are not the place where it increases.
Moreover, the desire realm is its dwelling place,
but the form and formless realms are not its dwelling places.
Moreover, the desire realm has its outflow and karmic retribution fruits,
because the form and formless realms do not have those homogeneous and retributive results.
Furthermore, the desire realm has those five classes of universal results.
The form and formless realms do not have those five classes of universal results, therefore.
Furthermore, the desire realm does not have their ultimate antidote.
The form and formless realms have their ultimate antidote, therefore.
Furthermore, if one moment suddenly takes the three realms as its object, whether suffering or its cause,
how does it take them as its object? Is it like taking the desire realm and increasing it, and also taking the form and formless realms in the same way?
Or is it like taking the form and formless realms and not increasing them,
and also taking the desire realm in the same way?
If so, what is wrong?
If it is like taking the desire realm and increasing it, and also taking the form and formless realms in the same way, then the realms should be mixed up.
If it is like taking the form and formless realms and not increasing them, and also taking the desire realm in the same way, then it would not be reasonable.
Because there are no afflictions that take as their objects dharmas of their own realm but do not increase in accordance with their objects and concomitants.
Because those that take as their objects dharmas of their own stage must have the bonds of their objects and concomitants.
If in a single moment one suddenly takes as objects the three realms, whether suffering or its causes,
there are those that increase in accordance with their objects and those that do not increase in accordance with their objects.
There must also be those that increase in accordance with their concomitants and those that do not increase in accordance with their concomitants.
This would contradict this principle of cause and effect, and also destroy the concomitants.
Do not let there be this fault.
Therefore, the principle of taking as objects one's own realm and other realms at different times is well established.
Thus, the wrong views that are eliminated by seeing suffering and its causes in the first trance state
are able to take as objects the suffering and its causes in the eight stages, but not simultaneously.
That is to say, in different moments they take as objects the first trance state,
and in different moments they take as objects the upper seven stages.
In this way, up to the wrong views that are eliminated by seeing suffering and its causes in the sphere of nothingness,

they are able to take as objects the suffering and its causes in two stages, but not simultaneously. That is to say, in different moments they take as objects their own stage,ğŸ”½and in different moments they take as objects the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The objects of the other moments of the same level are the same as above.
The wrong views that are eliminated by seeing suffering and its cause in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception
only take the suffering and its cause of their own level as objects.
The wrong views that are eliminated by seeing cessation in the desire realm only take the cessation of the various conditioned factors of the desire realm as objects.
Why are the wrong views eliminated by seeing suffering and its cause in the desire realm able to take the suffering and its cause of the three realms as objects?
Why are the wrong views eliminated by seeing cessation in the desire realm only able to take the cessation of the various conditioned factors of the desire realm as objects?
Venerable PÄrÅ›va says:
If a dharma is attached to by craving in the desire realm and is grasped by the view of self as self or what belongs to self,
then the cessation of these dharmas should be taken as objects by the wrong views eliminated by seeing cessation in the desire realm.
These afflictions are unable to take other realms as objects. This is also the same.
Some say: Suffering and its cause are conditioned dharmas that mutually attract each other in one's own realm and other realms.
Therefore, those wrong views are able to take other realms as objects.
The truth of cessation is unconditioned. There is no meaning of mutual attraction between one's own realm and other realms.
Therefore, those wrong views do not take other realms as objects.
Thus, wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into cessation in the first meditative absorption
only take the cessation of the various activities in the first meditative absorption as their object.
Up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into cessation
only take the cessation of the various activities in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as their object.
Wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into the path in the realm of desire only take the antidote to the various activities in the realm of desire as their object.
Question: Why can wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into suffering and into origination in the realm of desire take suffering and origination of the three realms as their objects?
Why can wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into the path in the realm of desire only take the antidote to the various activities in the realm of desire as their object?
Venerable PÄrÅ›va says:
If a dharma is one to which craving in the realm of desire is attached, and to which the view of the aggregates as a self clings as me and mine,
then the antidote to that dharma should be taken as the object of wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into the path in the realm of desire.
Those afflictions cannot take other realms as their objects. This is also so.
Some say: The objects of wrong views abandoned by the path of insight into suffering and into origination in the realm of desire are not antidotes, so they can take other stages as their objects.
Because the objects of the wrong views abandoned by the path of seeing in the desire realm are the antidotes themselves, they cannot take other realms as objects.
Regarding this, some say:
The wrong views abandoned by the path of seeing in the desire realm
Only take the category of dharma cognition of the stage of access concentration as their object.
Because only that is the antidote to their abandonment.
The discussion says:
It should be said:
Because they are of the same type as the category of dharma cognition of the six stages,
Because they are all antidotes to the destruction of the desire realm.
In this way, the wrong views abandoned by the path of seeing in the first meditative absorption
Can take the category of subsequent cognition of the nine stages as their object.
Up to the wrong views abandoned by the path of seeing in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception
Can take the category of subsequent cognition of the nine stages as their object.
Question: Why can the wrong views abandoned by the path of cessation only take the cessation of the various activities of their own stage as their object?
Can the wrong views abandoned by the path of seeing take the category of dharma cognition of the six stages as their object,
Or can they take the category of subsequent cognition of the nine stages as their object?
Answer: The cessations of one's own stage and other stages are not mutually causal.
because the noble paths of the various stages are causes for each other.
Question: If this is so, then the paths of the classes of Dharma knowledge and subsequent knowledge are also causes for each other.
Why does wrong view to be eliminated by the path of insight not take all of them as objects?
Some say: Wrong view to be eliminated by the path of insight can also take as objects the paths of the classes of Dharma knowledge and subsequent knowledge.
Because they are causes for each other.
Because the paths of the class of Dharma knowledge can also counteract the two upper realms.
The judges say:
One should not make this statement.
Because the paths of the class of subsequent knowledge are not the counteragents of dharmas of the realm of desire.
Although the paths of the class of Dharma knowledge are counteragents to the two upper realms, they are not the first nor are they complete.
Also, because the classes of Dharma knowledge and subsequent knowledge are different kinds.
Some say: The paths of the class of subsequent knowledge of the nine stages are the counteragents to the elimination of the eight upper stages.
They are then the objects of the wrong views to be eliminated by the path of insight of those stages, but not the paths of the other stages.
The judges say:
One should not make this statement.
Because there are many kinds of counteragents.
Moreover, the class of subsequent cognition is the cause of each other because their kinds are the same.
Question: A single moment of latent tendency cannot universally take all as objects,
and there is also no principle of universal increase.
Why is it called universal?
Answer: Because it is said based on their kind and continuity, there is no error.
However, regarding universal latent tendencies and universal causes, four sentences should be made.
There are universal latent tendencies that are not universal causes.
This refers to future universal latent tendencies.
There are universal causes that are not universal latent tendencies.
This refers to associated and coexistent dharmas concomitant with past and present universal latent tendencies.
There are universal latent tendencies that are also universal causes.
This refers to past and present universal latent tendencies.
There are those that are neither universal latent tendencies nor universal causes.
If it is said without relying on their kind,
it should be said: Except for the above characteristics.
If it is said relying on their kind, it should be said: Associated and coexistent dharmas concomitant with future universal latent tendencies.
Question: Are all defiled dharmas caused by dharmas that are eliminated by seeing?
If so, what is the error?
If all defiled dharmas are caused by dharmas that are eliminated by seeing,
then they are causes when not yet eliminated and also when already eliminated.
What is the difference between not yet eliminated and already eliminated?
Moreover, if this is so,
why are defiled dharmas eliminated by cultivation in the noble ones
sometimes arisen and sometimes not arisen?
Those that are not arisenğŸ”½are the class of attachment to nonexistence, pride, and extreme anger.
Those that are arisen are the remaining greed, hatred, pride, and ignorance.
Moreover, if this is so,
how can the VijÃ±ÄnakÄya ÅšÄstra be understood?
It says, Are there any unwholesome dharmas
that only have unwholesome causes?
The answer is: There are.
When the noble ones retrogress and depart from the desire realm,
the first defiled volition appears in the present.
If all defiled dharmas
are not all caused by dharmas eliminated by seeing,
How can the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra be understood?
It says:
What are the dharmas with the seen as their cause?
It means all defiled dharmas,
and the retribution of the dharmas with the seen.
Moreover, if it is so,
it also contradicts its own statement.
What are the dharmas with the indeterminate as their cause?
It means the indeterminate conditioned dharmas,
and all unwholesome dharmas.
Moreover, if it is so,
it also contradicts its own statement.
Or there is the truth of suffering that takes the view of self as its cause,
but does not take the view of self as its cause.
It means excluding the past and present views that eliminate suffering,
and so on, up to excluding the future view of self and the dharmas associated with it,
the birth, old age, duration, and impermanence of the remaining defiled truths of suffering, etc.
Moreover, if it is so,
how can the VijÃ±ÄnakÄya-Å›Ästra be understood?
It says:
The unwholesome eye consciousness,
up to the unwholesome mental consciousness,
all take the unwholesome and indeterminate as their causes.
Answer: It should be said:
All defiled dharmas
all have the dharmas that are eliminated by seeing as their cause.
Question: If that is so, then both that which is not yet eliminated and that which is already eliminated can be causes.
What is the difference?
Answer: The name itself is the difference.
That is to say, the state before it is not yet eliminated is called the cause of that which is not yet eliminated.
The state after it is already eliminated is called the cause of that which is already eliminated.
Furthermore, the previous state is not yet destroyed by the antidote.
Although the later state is also a cause,
it has already been destroyed by the antidote.
Furthermore, the previous state obstructs the noble path within one's own body.
Although the later state is also a cause,
it does not obstruct the noble path within one's own body.ğŸ”½Furthermore, the previous state
can give rise to something like smoke and flames within one's own body.
Although the later state is also a cause,
it can no longer give rise to something like smoke and flames within one's own body.
Furthermore, the previous state
can do things that are to be despised and defiled within one's own body.
Although in the later stage it is also a cause,
it can no longer perform blameworthy and defiled actions in one's own continuum.
Furthermore, in the previous stage,
it can accomplish what should be done in one's own continuum.
Although in the later stage it is also a cause,
it can no longer accomplish what should be done in one's own continuum.
Furthermore, in the previous stage,
it can accomplish the function of homogeneous cause and pervasive cause in one's own continuum.
Although in the later stage it is also a cause,
it can no longer accomplish the function of homogeneous cause and pervasive cause in one's own continuum.
Furthermore, in the previous stage,
it can accomplish the effect of natural outflow and the effect of retribution in one's own continuum.
Although in the later stage it is also a cause,
it can no longer accomplish the effect of natural outflow and the effect of retribution in one's own continuum.
Furthermore, in the previous stage,
it can take an effect and give an effect in one's own continuum.
Although in the later stage it is also a cause,
it can no longer take an effect and give an effect in one's own continuum.
This is called the distinction between what is not yet eliminated and what is already eliminated.
Question: If that is so, why do the noble ones cultivate to eliminate defiled dharmas?
Are there any that arise and any that do not arise?
Answer: Dharmas eliminated by insight may be either proximate causes for the continuity of those [defiled dharmas],
or distant causes for their non-continuity.
If they are proximate causes for the continuity of those [defiled dharmas],
the noble ones do not give rise to them.
If they are distant causes for the non-continuity of those [defiled dharmas],
the noble ones still give rise to them.
Furthermore, if one has already attained the non-analytical cessation of those [defiled dharmas],
the noble ones do not give rise to them.
If one has not yet attained the non-analytical cessation of those [defiled dharmas],
the noble ones still give rise to them.
Furthermore, if the arising of those [defiled dharmas] is definitely based on the nature of ordinary beings,
the noble ones do not give rise to them.
If it is not definite,
the noble ones still give rise to them.
Furthermore, if the arising of those [defiled dharmas] definitely obstructs the nature of the noble ones,
the noble ones do not give rise to them.
If it is not so,
the noble ones still give rise to them.
Question: Why do the noble ones not give rise to craving for non-existence?
Answer: Because they are nourished by the view of annihilation.
Because they appear immediately after the view of annihilation.
Because all noble ones have already eliminated the view of annihilation, they do not arise.
Question: Why do noble ones not give rise to the various types of pride?
Answer: Because they are nourished by the view of the aggregates as the self.
Because they appear immediately after the view of the aggregates as the self.
Because all noble ones have already eliminated the view of the aggregates as the self, they do not arise.
Question: Why do noble ones not give rise to the extreme anger that binds?
Answer: Because they are nourished by wrong views.
Because they appear immediately after wrong views.
Because all noble ones have already eliminated wrong views, they do not arise.
Question: If that is so, how should we understand the Explanation of the Aggregates of Consciousness?
It says:
Are there any unwholesome dharmas
that only have unwholesome causes?
Answer: There are.
And so on, in detail.
Answer: Because it is said based on causes that have not yet been eliminated, there is no contradiction.
That is to say, when unwholesome volition first arises, there are two kinds of causes.
One is already severed.
Two are not yet severed.
That treatise only explains the cause of what is not yet severed.
Moreover, because it explains the cause of what is unwholesome, there is no contradiction.
That is to say, when that unwholesome volition first arises, there are two kinds of causes.
One is unwholesome.
Two are indeterminate.
That treatise only explains the cause of what is unwholesome.
Moreover, because it explains the cause of one's own category, there is no contradiction.
That is to say, when that unwholesome volition first arises, there are two kinds of causes.
One is of one's own category.
Two are of another category.
That treatise only explains the cause of one's own category.
Moreover, because it explains the cause that is not a universal, there is no contradiction.
That is to say, when that unwholesome volition first arises, there are two kinds of causes.
One is a universal.
Two are not universal.
That treatise only explains the cause that is not a universal.
Moreover, because it explains the cause that is not shared, there is no contradiction.
That is to say, when that unwholesome volition first arises, there are two kinds of causes.
One is shared.
Two are not shared.
That treatise only explains it based on the uncommon cause.
Question: When the noble ones have not yet abandoned the defilements of desire,
those defiled intentions are also caused by unwholesomeness.
Why does that treatise say that when one subsequently regresses,
Answer: At that time, those intentions that were previously unaccomplished now become accomplished.
Previously unfettered, now fettered.
Previously dead, now born.
Therefore, it is said in a biased way.
Question: The subsequent defiled intentions are also caused by unwholesomeness.
Why does that treatise only speak of the initial arising?
Answer: At that time, they are first severed and now continue.
Previously useless, now useful.
Previously dead, now born.
Therefore, it is said in a biased way.
There is an explanation:
All defiled dharmas,
Are not all caused by the dharmas that are severed by seeing.
Question: If so,
The JÃ±ÄnaprasthÄna and VijÃ±ÄnakÄya treatises say,
How can this be understood?
Answer: They speak in general terms.
If spoken separately,
It should be said like this:
There is defiled form
that takes the dharmas eliminated by seeing as its cause.
Not all defiled form.
Up to defiled consciousness
that takes the dharmas eliminated by seeing as its cause.
Not all defiled consciousness.
The judges say:
They should not make this statement.
Because that treatise says that all defiled dharmas take the dharmas eliminated by seeing as their cause.
Because all unwholesome dharmas take the indeterminate as their cause.
The other defiled truths of suffering, etc. all take the view of self-existence as their cause.
The six unwholesome consciousnesses all take the unwholesome and indeterminate as their cause.
The previous statement is correct.
The Venerable SÄmadatta distinguishes the defiled dharmas as different.
He says:
There are dharmas eliminated by seeing suffering
that only take the dharmas eliminated by seeing suffering as their cause.
There are dharmas eliminated by seeing suffering that only take the dharmas eliminated by seeing the origin as their cause.
There are none that take both as their cause.
The same applies to dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origination [of suffering].
In reality, there is no such case, but it is explained through discrimination.
Suppose an Ärya, having realized suffering, has not yet realized the origination [of suffering].

When arising from the noble path, dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origination [of suffering] only take dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origination [of suffering] as their causes.
Dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origination [of suffering] that can be made to appear take dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering as their causes.
Those that cannot be made to appear.
Because their causes have already been eliminated.

translated: There are dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing cessation that only take dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing cessation as their causes.ğŸ”½There are dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing cessation that only take dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing suffering as their causes.ğŸ”½There are dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing cessation that only take dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the origination [of suffering] as their causes.
There are dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing cessation that only take dharmas to be eliminated by [the paths of] seeing suffering and the origination [of suffering] as their causes.
There are none that take three as their causes.
Defiled dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the path and by cultivation are also like this.
In reality, there is no such case, but it is explained through discrimination.
Suppose an Ärya, having realized cessation, has not yet realized the path.
The dharmas abandoned by the path of seeing, which are only with the dharmas abandoned by the path of seeing as their cause, can be made to appear.
The dharmas abandoned by the path of seeing, which are only with the dharmas abandoned by seeing suffering and origination as their cause, cannot be made to appear.
Because their causes have already been eliminated.
In this way, the noble ones in the path of cultivation,
the defiled dharmas abandoned by cultivation, which are only with the dharmas abandoned by cultivation as their cause,
can be made to appear.
The defiled dharmas abandoned by cultivation,
which are only with the dharmas abandoned by seeing suffering and origination as their cause,
cannot be made to appear because their causes have already been eliminated.
However, when the noble ones are free from the defilements of desire, the defiled dharmas abandoned by cultivation in the desire realm,
if they are only with the dharmas abandoned by cultivation as their cause,
if they are only with the dharmas abandoned by seeing suffering and origination as their cause,
they are combined into one group and gradually eliminated in nine grades.
When they later retrogress, the defiled dharmas abandoned by cultivation in the desire realm,

Those that are only established as having only the cause of the eliminated by cultivation are still established. Those that are only established as having only the cause of the eliminated by insight are not established.
Because the cause has already been eliminated.
Moreover, at that time, only those that have the cause of the eliminated by cultivation are established.
Among the defiled dharmas eliminated by cultivation, those in the future are still established.
Those in the past are not established.
Because they will not arise again in the present.
The judges say:
They should not make this statement.
How can the same counteraction eliminate afflictions?
When they later regress, some are reestablished and some are not established.
Moreover, they cannot explain the statements in the Prakaraá¹‡a and VijÃ±ÄnakÄya.
Therefore, the previous explanation is correct.
Question: Love is equally separated in all realms, stages, and categories.
Why can the universal latent afflictions increase in other categories but not in other realms or stages?
Answer: The universal latent afflictions have the effect of outflow or the effect of retribution with regard to dharmas in other categories, and therefore they can increase.
Because there is no outflow or karmic retribution fruit in other realms and stages, they do not increase.
Moreover, because the coarse and subtle of one's own stage and other parts are similar, they can increase.
Because the upper stages are subtle, they cannot increase.
Question: Do the universal karmic retributions and the non-universal karmic retributions mutually become causes for each other?
Some say:
The universal karmic retributions are causes for the non-universal karmic retributions.
The non-universal karmic retributions are not all causes for the universal karmic retributions.
Just as the universal latent afflictions are causes for the non-universal latent afflictions.
The non-universal latent afflictions of other parts cannot be causes for the universal latent afflictions. The karmic retributions are also like this.
The judges say:
They should not say this.
The dharmas of latent afflictions are different.
The dharmas of karmic retributions are different.
The latent afflictions have five parts, while the karmic retributions are only eliminated by cultivation. Therefore,
One should say:
The universal karmic retributions are causes for the universal karmic retributions.
It is also the cause of non-universal karmic ripening.
Non-universal karmic ripening is the cause of non-universal karmic ripening.
It is also the cause of universal karmic ripening.
Because of the same realm, the same category, the same nature, and so on.
Question: What is the intrinsic nature of the universal cause?
Answer: All past and present universal latent afflictions,
And the dharmas associated with them and coexisting with them.
The intrinsic nature has already been explained.
The reason will now be explained.
Question: Why is it called the universal cause?
What is the meaning of universal?
Answer: The meaning of being the cause universally is the meaning of universal.
Furthermore, the meaning of being able to universally perceive is the meaning of universal.
Furthermore, the meaning of universally increasing is the meaning of universal.
This universal cause only exists in the past and present two time periods, and has the outflow effect.
What is the karmic ripening cause?
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Question: Why does this treatise discuss this?
Answer: In order to stop other schools and reveal the correct principle.
Some say that apart from volition there is no cause of retribution,
and apart from feeling there is no result of retribution.
This is like the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas.
To refute this view, it is said that the cause of retribution and the result of retribution both consist of the five aggregates.
Or some say that only mind and mental activities are the cause of retribution and the result of retribution.
This is like the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghikas.

To refute this view, it is said that these causes and results also consist of form and non-psychophysical elements.ğŸ”½Or some say that only mind, mental activities, and form are the cause of retribution and the result of retribution.
To refute this view, it is said that these also consist of non-psychophysical elements.
Or some say that the cause of retribution necessarily abandons its own substance and its result ripens.
They say:
The cause of retribution necessarily enters the past in order to give its result.
Since the past has already ceased, it has no substance of its own.
To refute this view, it is said that the cause of retribution still has real substance when it reaches the stage of ripening its result.
Or there are some who hold the view that
if the cause of the various karmic retributions has not yet matured, its substance always exists.
When its fruit has matured, its substance is then destroyed.
Like the KÄÅ›yapÄ«yas, they say:
Just as a seed, if the sprout has not yet arisen, its substance always exists. When the sprout arises, it is destroyed.
The various causes of karmic retributions are also like this.
In order to stop this view and show that
even though the fruit of karmic retribution has already matured, its substance still exists,
Or there are some who hold the view that
the created good and evil have no fruits of suffering and happiness, like the non-Buddhists.
In order to stop this view and show that good and evil karma have fruits of suffering and happiness,
this treatise is composed.
What is the cause of karmic retribution?
Answer: The various mind and mental factors,
experiencing the karmic retribution of form, mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with mind.
These mind and mental factors are the cause of karmic retribution for that karmic retribution.
Among them, the various mind and mental factors refer to
all unwholesome, wholesome, and contaminated mind and mental factors.
This statement also includes the form that accompanies them.
Because the dissociated formative forces have the same effect as the mind and mental factors.ğŸ”½The form that is a ripening means
the form aggregate.
That is, the five sense organs such as the eye, and form, smell, taste, and touch.
The mind means
the consciousness aggregate.
That is, the six consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness.
The mental factors means
the three aggregates.
That is, feeling, conceptualization, volition, and so forth.ğŸ”½The dissociated formative forces meansğŸ”½the formative forces aggregate.
That is, the life faculty, the common lot of sentient beings, and so forth.
This shows that the cause of ripening and the effect of ripening are both common to the five aggregates.
Next, the bodily and verbal actions
experience the ripening of form, mind, mental factors, and the dissociated formative forces.
These bodily and verbal actions are the cause of ripening for that ripening.
Question: Bodily and verbal actions that accompany the mind have the same effect as the mind, so
as has already been explained above.ğŸ”½Here, what is the meaning of the phrase bodily and verbal actions
that is mentioned again?
Answer: The two karmas of body and speech that are neither good nor bad, and the avijÃ±apti that arises based on the vijÃ±apti karma, do not follow the mind.
This samÄdhi is able to attract the result of retribution, therefore it is called the samÄdhi of attracting.
Some say:
Here, the vijÃ±apti of body and speech, and the avijÃ±apti that arises in that moment, are said to be of the same result.
That explanation is unreasonable.ğŸ”½The vijÃ±apti karma of body and speech, and the avijÃ±apti of body and speech that arise together with it,
are not of the same result.
Because they are not mutually co-existent causes.
Some say:
Although the vijÃ±apti karma and the avijÃ±apti of body and speech that arise based on the vijÃ±apti are not of the same result,
they definitely experience the result of retribution at the same time, because they arise from the same mind.
That explanation is unreasonable.
They are not mutually co-existent causes.
How can it be definitely said that they experience the result of retribution in the same moment?
However, the vijÃ±apti and avijÃ±apti are not mutually co-existent causes, therefore their results of retribution are different.
Within the vijÃ±apti karma, the seven branches, etc.,
each individually attract the result of retribution.
Each of the branches, etc., has many atoms.ğŸ”½Each atom has distinctions of past, present, and future.
In each of the three times there are many moments.
Each moment has different ripening fruits, because they are not co-existent causes.
Unmanifested action is also like this.
The previous seven branches that follow the mind, the unmanifested action that can mutually be co-existent causes, therefore have the same ripening fruit.
The manifested and unmanifested actions explained here
also include those that follow and arise together, because they have the same fruit. The received ripening should be understood as before.
Next, the formations that are not associated with mind, the ripening of feeling, the form of ripening, the mental factors, and the formations not associated with mind,
these formations not associated with mind are the ripening cause for that ripening.
This is called the ripening cause.
The question is: the mental factors, the manifested and unmanifested actions, the arising together that follows, etc.,
as explained above,
because they have the same fruit.
What formations not associated with mind are now explained again?

Answer: Now it is said that the attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation, all unwholesome and wholesome contaminated attainments, and their concomitant arising and other characteristics,
have not been explained before.
Question: What kind of retribution does the attainment of non-perception receive?
Some say:
The attainment of non-perception receives the retribution of non-perception and form.
The retribution of life-force and general life-span,
is the result of the fourth dhyÄna with mind.
The retribution of the other aggregates is a common result.
Some say the attainment of non-perception receives the retribution of non-perception and form.
The retribution of life-force is the result of the fourth dhyÄna with mind.
The retribution of the other aggregates is a common result.
Some say:
The attainment of non-perception receives the retribution of non-perception and form.
The retribution of the other aggregates is a common result.
Some say:
The attainment of non-perception only receives the retribution of non-perception. The retribution of the other aggregates is a common result.
Question: If life-force is also a result of karma that is not retribution,
How can we understand the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra?
It says:
One dharma is the retribution of karma but not karma itself, namely the faculty of life.
The answer is: All faculties of life are only retribution.
All retributions are manifested by karma.
Based on this secret meaning, it is said.
However, in reality, the faculty of life is also not produced by karma.
Furthermore, that treatise is based on conventional truth, not on ultimate truth.
It means that when people in the world see someone with a short lifespan, they say:
This person has done karma that results in a short lifespan.
When they see someone with a long lifespan, they say:
This person has done karma that results in a long lifespan.
Some say:
In the state of non-perception in the heaven of non-perception, one also experiences the effect of the karma of the fourth dhyana with a mind.
In the state with a mind, one also experiences the effect of the attainment of non-perception.
Question: If one experiences the effect of a mind in the state without a mind,
and experiences the effect of a state without a mind in the state with a mind,
how can cause and effect not be inverted?
Answer: It is like having form karma and also experiencing formless effects.
Formless karma also receives form as its effect.
But there is no error of cause and effect being inverted.
This is also like that.
Venerable SÄ“madÄsa said:
The attainment of non-perception receives the ripening of non-perception and homogeneity.
That life faculty and form are ripening.
They are the effect of the fourth dhyÄna with mind.
Those mind and mental factors, and the other factors not directly associated with mind,
are all not ripening.
The judges say:
They should not say this.
Because homogeneity as ripening is the effect of karma.
Among those mind and mental factors, and the other factors not directly associated with mind, there are also those that are ripening.
Therefore Venerable Buddhadeva said:
The attainment of non-perception receives the ripening of non-perception.
That life faculty and homogeneity
are the effect of the fourth dhyÄna with mind.
The other aggregates as ripening are common effects.
The judges say:
They should not say this.
The five sense faculties such as the eye are results of karma.
This should be said:
The karmic result of the attainment of non-perception is only the result of the attainment of non-perception.
The karmic result of the life faculty, general characteristics, and five material faculties is only the result of the fourth dhyÄna with mind.
The karmic result of the other aggregates is common.
Question: What karmic result does the attainment of cessation experience?
Answer: It experiences the karmic result of the four aggregates of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Excluding the life faculty and general characteristics.
They are only the result of karma.
Question: What karmic result do the various attainments experience?
Answer: The various attainments experience the karmic result of form, mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with the mind.
Form refers to form, smell, taste, and touch.
Not the five material faculties.
They are the result of karma.
Mind and mental factors refer to the feeling of pain, the feeling of pleasure, and the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant.
And the factors associated with them. Factors not directly associated with the mind refer to the attainment, birth, aging, duration, and impermanence of all [dharmas].
Venerable Saá¹ƒghabhadra says:
Obtainment can also receive the five sense faculties such as the eye, and the homogeneous character of the life faculty, as its karmic maturation.
He explains it like this:
Although each individual obtainment lacks the power to attract the homogeneous character, etc., when many obtainments accumulate, they can attract it. However, it only attracts a dull body,
like an earthworm, etc. It obtains the form that is to be attracted, which is nine sense bases excluding sound.
The mind and mental factors belong to the three aggregates of sensation, etc. The dissociated formations
are the homogeneous character, the life faculty, the obtainments, birth, duration, senescence, and desinence.
The judges say:
He should not explain it like this.
The obtainments of different faculties are not co-existent causes.
Even if billions of them accumulate, what benefit is there?
Because they are not a single effect, they cannot jointly attract the homogeneous character, etc.
Venerable Subhagupta explains it like this:
Obtainment cannot attract the homogeneous character, etc.
When karma attracts the homogeneous character, etc., in the sense faculties such as the eye,
it can only attract form, smell, taste, and touch.
The commentary says:
They should not say this.
Do not let the formless realm have no retribution as its effect.
Therefore, one should know that the first explanation is correct.
The PaÃ±caskandhaprakaraá¹‡a says:
What is the cause of retribution?
It refers to all unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas.
What is the difference between this and the cause of retribution explained in this treatise?
The answer is: This is not definitive, while that is definitive.
This has other meanings, while that does not.
This has other causes, while that does not.
This is based on the conventional, while that is based on the ultimate.
This has implications, while that does not.
Furthermore, this explains the cause of retribution that has already arisen.
That explains the cause of retribution that has already arisen and that which has not yet arisen.
This explains the cause of retribution that gives rise to effects.
That explains the cause of retribution that gives rise to effects and that which has not yet given rise to effects.
Furthermore, this explains the effects of new karma.
That explains the effects of new and old karma.
Furthermore, this explains the cause of retribution in the past.
They explain the cause of karmic ripening in the three times.
Next, this explains the cause of karmic ripening that is currently giving results.
They explain the cause of karmic ripening that has already given, is currently giving, and will give results.
This is the difference between what is explained here and what is explained there.
Why is it only explained here that the cause of karmic ripening is currently giving results?
The answer is: The characteristics of that which is currently giving results are evident.
Furthermore, because the five destinies and various sentient beings are established in the present results.
At that time, this cause is ultimately used to give results.
It displays the cause of results that will be given and has been given.
For the sake of convenience in meaning.
Here, it only explains the cause of results that are currently being given.
Furthermore, in the desire realm, there is a cause of karmic ripening of four aggregates that obtains one result.
Namely, wholesome and unwholesome mind and mental factors, and their arising, etc.
There is a cause of karmic ripening of two aggregates that obtains one result.
Namely, wholesome and unwholesome bodily and verbal actions, and their arising, etc.
There is a cause of karmic ripening of one aggregate that obtains one result.
Namely, attainment and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth.
In the form realm, the karmic maturation cause of the five aggregates has one effect.
Namely, form that accompanies [the mind], mind, mental factors, and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth.
The karmic maturation cause of the four aggregates has one effect.
Namely, wholesome mind, mental factors, and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth, without form that accompanies [the mind].
The karmic maturation cause of the two aggregates has one effect.
Namely, wholesome bodily and verbal expression, and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth.
The karmic maturation cause of the one aggregate has one effect.
Namely, attaining the attainment of non-perception, and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth.
In the formless realm, the karmic maturation cause of the four aggregates has one effect.
Namely, wholesome mind, mental factors, and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth.
The karmic maturation cause of the one aggregate has one effect.
Namely, attaining the attainment of cessation, and the arising of those [dharmas] and so forth.
Next, there is karma that only experiences the karmic maturation of one sense base.
Namely, karma that obtains the life faculty and the homogeneity of sentient beings.
That karma only experiences the karmic maturation of the dharma sense base.
There is karma that only experiences the karmic maturation of two sense bases.
It means karma that obtains the mental faculty.
That karma only experiences the ripening of the mental faculty and the dharma faculty.
Obtaining the karma of the faculty of touch also experiences the ripening of two faculties.
Namely, the faculty of touch and the dharma faculty.
Obtaining the karma of the body faculty experiences the ripening of three faculties.
Namely, the body faculty, the faculty of touch, and the dharma faculty.
Obtaining the karma of the faculties of form, smell, and taste is also like this.
Each experiences the ripening of its own faculty, the faculty of touch, and the dharma faculty.
Obtaining the karma of the eye faculty experiences the ripening of four faculties.
Namely, the eye faculty, the body faculty, the faculty of touch, and the dharma faculty.
Obtaining the karma of the faculties of ear, nose, and tongue is also like this - each experiences the ripening of its own faculty, the body faculty, the faculty of touch, and the dharma faculty.
Other masters say:
All the great elements give rise to form and sound.
The forms of the desire realm are not separate from smell and taste.
They say:
Obtaining the karma of the eye faculty experiences the ripening of seven faculties.
Namely, the eye faculty, the body faculty, and the ripening of form, smell, taste, touch, and the dharma faculty.
Obtaining the karma of the faculties of ear, nose, and tongue is also like this.
That is, each receives the ripening of its own place, the body place, and the places of form, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
Obtaining the karma of the body place receives the ripening of six places.
That is, the body place and the ripening of form, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
Obtaining the karma of the form place receives the ripening of five places.
That is, the ripening of form, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
Obtaining the karma of smell, taste, and touch places is also like this.
That is, each receives the ripening of form, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
This is said to be the definite obtainment.
The indefinite obtainment is not fixed in number.
However, there is karma that can receive the ripening of eight places.
There is karma that can receive the ripening of nine places.ğŸ”½There is karma that can receive the ripening of ten places.
There is karma that can receive the ripening of eleven places.
All except for the sound place.
Question: Why is there karma that can receive the ripening of many places?
Is there karma that can receive the ripening of few places?
Answer: If karma has various functions and obtains various fruits,
It receives the ripening of many places.
If an action does not have various potencies, it cannot produce various effects.ğŸ”½If it has various potencies, it can produce various effects.
If an external seed has various potencies, it can produce various effects.
Like rice, sugarcane, grapes, lotus roots, etc.
If it does not have various potencies, it cannot produce various effects.
Like the seeds of the SÅ«ká¹£mÄ plant and tÄla tree, etc.
There is a plant called SÅ«ká¹£mÄ in the marshes.
One kind, one stem, but several feet tall.
There are few leaves on top, shaped like a canopy.
There is a tÄla tree over a hundred cubits tall.
There are also few leaves on top, shaped like a canopy.
Although the trunk is tall, there are very few fruits.
Actions are also like this.
However, an action of one lifetime can produce effects in the three periods of time.
There is no action of the three periods of time that produces effects in one lifetime.
An action of one instant can produce effects of many instants.
There is no action of many instants that produces effects of one instant.
Because the effects of good and bad actions are indeterminate.
Because the effect produced does not decrease the cause.
Question: Do those who create karma first create the karma that attracts the commonality of beings,
or do they first create the karma that perfects the commonality of beings?
Some say:
First, one creates the karma that attracts, and later one creates the karma that perfects.
If one does not first attract, then there is nothing to perfect.
It is like a painter who first outlines the image and then fills in the details with various colors.
This is also like that.
Other masters say:
First, one creates the karma that perfects, and later one creates the karma that attracts.
For example, a bodhisattva first creates the karma that perfects over three incalculable eons,
and later, within a hundred great eons, he creates the karma that attracts.
Those who say this:
This is not definite.ğŸ”½Some first create the karma that attracts and later create the karma that perfects,
while others first create the karma that perfects and later create the karma that attracts.
This is because the creator of karma acts according to his intention.
Furthermore, there are three kinds of karma that experience retribution:
1. Karma that is experienced in the present life,
2. Karma that is experienced in the next life,
Third, karma to be experienced in a subsequent life.
As for karma to be experienced in the present life,
if karma is created and increased in this life,
the result of karmic maturation is experienced in this very life,
not in any other life.
As for karma to be experienced in the next life,
if karma is created and increased in this life,
the result of karmic maturation is experienced in the next life,
not in any other life.
As for karma to be experienced in a subsequent life,
if karma is created and increased in this life,
in the third or fourth life or later,
the result of karmic maturation is experienced in sequence.
However, the term maturation has many meanings.
In some cases, the same effect is called maturation,
such as saying that craving is the maturation of the link of feeling.

In some cases, nourishment is called maturation, such as saying that food and drink and medicine bring about the maturation of happiness. In some cases, dream events are called maturation, such as saying that one dreams of such and such kinds of maturation.
In some cases, abundance and scarcity are called maturation,
such as saying:ğŸ”½The maturation of giving is great wealth.
The stars are on this road.
There will be such differences in abundance and scarcity.
In some places, the Brahma King calls it different ripening.
As it is said, Great Sage, I have not yet left. Observe this light, what is its different ripening?
In some places, different ripening is called different ripening.
As it is said here, the ripening of form and so forth is called different ripening.
Ripening is of two kinds.
The first is of the same kind.
The second is of a different kind.ğŸ”½Ripening of the same kind means
the outflow effect.
It means that good produces good,
evil produces evil,
and indeterminate produces indeterminate.ğŸ”½Ripening of a different kind means
the ripening effect.
It means that good and evil produce indeterminate effects.
This indeterminate effect is produced by good and evil causes of a different kind, so it is called ripening.
If ripening of a different kind is called the ripening effect,
why is the evil destiny called non-ripening?
Answer: It is also ripening.
However, because they are lowly, they are called unripe.
It is like lowly villages, cities, etc., which are called non-villages, etc.
Moreover, because they are overripe, they are called unripe.
It is like a clumsy potter who burns various earthenware.
Using a lot of firewood and grass, the vessels all become scorched and melted.
They are not suitable for use and are also called unripe.
The evil destinies are also like this.
Because the fruits of suffering are too excessive, they are called unripe.
Moreover, because there is no wholesome ripening in them, they are called unripe.
Question: Animals and ghosts also experience wholesome fruits.
How can all evil destinies be called unripe?
Answer: Because their wholesome fruits are few, they are also called non-existent.
It is like a river with little water, which is also called waterless.
Moreover, although these destinies have wholesome fruits,
they are unable to cultivate other superior wholesome dharmas.
Therefore, they are called unripe.
It is like a farmer who harvests very little, which is also called unripe.
However, in reality, the evil destinies have fruits of ripening.
Question: Why do unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas have ripening fruits,
while indeterminate and uncontaminated dharmas do not have ripening fruits?
Answer: The nature, conditions, and completeness or incompleteness are threefold, different,
like external seeds.
Like a firm seed placed in good soil,
watered, covered with manure,
the power of causes and conditions being complete, a sprout immediately grows.
In the same way, the nature of unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas is firm and real.
Placed in the field of existence, watered with the water of craving, covered with the other bonds,
the power of causes and conditions being complete, the sprout of existence is born.
Like a firm seed placed in a granary,
the conditions of water and manure being incomplete, a sprout cannot grow.
In the same way, although the substance of uncontaminated wholesome conditioned dharmas is firm and real,
it lacks the water of craving and the moist covering of the other bonds, so the sprout of existence does not grow.
Like a rotten seed, although placed in good soil, watered, and covered with manure,
the power of the cause being incomplete, a sprout cannot grow.
Thus, these neutral conditioned dharmas,
although moistened and covered by the water of craving and other bonds,
their substance is weak and feeble, and the sprouts do not grow.
Question: For what reason again do the pure dharmas have no retribution?
Answer: Not a field, not a vessel,
and so on, explaining in detail.
Next, if a dharma can cause the various existences, the various destinies, birth, old age, sickness and death to continue uninterrupted, it has a retribution.
Because the pure can cause the various existences, the various destinies, birth, old age, sickness and death to be ultimately cut off, it has no retribution.
Next, if a dharma can cause the various existences, the various destinies to gradually increase, it has a retribution.
Because the pure can cause the various existences, the various destinies to gradually decrease, it has no retribution.
Next, if a dharma is suffering, and the worldly birth, old age, sickness and death of the various existences and destinies is the practice of accumulating, it has a retribution.
Because the pure is suffering, and the worldly birth, old age, sickness and death of the various existences and destinies is the practice of cessation, it has no retribution.
Furthermore, if a dharma is the object of the view of self, it is the object of perversion.
It is the object of craving, it is the object of latent tendencies,
it is defiled, poisonous, impure, and turbid.
It falls into the truths of suffering and accumulation, and falls into the three existences, having a ripening fruit.
Because uncontaminated dharmas are not the same as those, they have no ripening fruit.
Furthermore, if uncontaminated dharmas have ripening,
then they would be superior causes obtaining inferior fruits.
The cause is uncontaminated wholesome conditioned dharmas.
The fruit is contaminated indeterminate dharmas.
Furthermore, if uncontaminated dharmas have ripening,
then they would cause the noble path to continue.
The continuation of the noble path contradicts reason.
Furthermore, if uncontaminated dharmas have ripening,
where will they be received?
If in the desire realm, it would not be reasonable.
Because uncontaminated dharmas are not bound to the desire realm.
Like karma in the form and formless realms.
If in the form realm, it would also not be reasonable.
Because uncontaminated dharmas are not bound to the form realm.
Like karma in the desire and formless realms.
If it were in the formless realm, it would also be unreasonable.
Because uncontaminated dharmas are not bound to the formless realm.
Like karma in the desire and form realms.
If it were outside the three realms, it would also be unreasonable.
Because outside the three realms there is no separate place.
Moreover, the uncontaminated holy path is the antidote to the retribution and the cause of retribution.
If it can also bring about the retribution of results,
it will also need an antidote to counteract it.
Because it is uncontaminated.ğŸ”½It will again bring about retribution, and in order to counteract that, it will again cultivate the holy path.
That holy path will again bring about retribution.
In this way, it would go on ad infinitum.
Then there would be no liberation or escape. Do not let there be this fault.
Therefore, uncontaminated dharmas have no retribution as a result.
Moreover, if uncontaminated dharmas bring about retribution,
then one would never attain nirvana.
The sages would not diligently cultivate and practice.
Because it attracts the dharmas of transmigration in birth and death.
Therefore, this pure [karma] has no retribution.
Question: For what other reason do indeterminate dharmas have no retribution?
Answer: Not a field, not a vessel...
Explained in detail.
Furthermore, if indeterminate dharmas have retribution,
is this retribution indeterminate, good, or bad?
If it is indeterminate,
why is it called retribution? Because it is not retribution of a different kind.
If it is good or bad, it is also not retribution.
Because the retribution is indeterminate.
Furthermore, if indeterminate dharmas have retribution,
because this retribution is indeterminate, it should have retribution.
That very retribution should be able to attract other retribution.
In this way, it would be an infinite regress.
Then there would be no liberation or escape.
Because of this fault, indeterminate dharmas have no retribution.
Due to these various reasons,
Only unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas
are karmic ripening causes.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 19
